messages.content: How is the verb <WORD>rë</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>rë</WORD>

<DEFINITION>to plan, went</DEFINITION>
<POS>Verb</POS>

<EXAMPLES>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>te meteré</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>I plan</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>rë uprayahi</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<LITERAL>went uprayahi</LITERAL>
</EXAMPLES>

<USAGE>Based on the provided examples, it seems the word <WORD>rë</WORD> has multiple meanings and can function as different parts of speech in Yanomami. However, there is not enough information to definitively determine full conjugation patterns if <WORD>rë</WORD> is a verb.</USAGE>

<GRAMMATICAL>If <WORD>rë</WORD> means 'to plan' (transitive verb):
- <YANOMAMI>te meteré</YANOMAMI> suggests a possible 1st person singular conjugation <YANOMAMI>te rë</YANOMAMI> meaning <TRANSLATION>I plan</TRANSLATION>

If <WORD>rë</WORD> means 'went' (intransitive verb):
- <YANOMAMI>rë uprayahi</YANOMAMI> could be a 3rd person singular past tense form</GRAMMATICAL>

<USAGE>Without a fuller paradigm showing subject/tense/aspect variations, I cannot provide complete conjugation tables. The examples indicate <WORD>rë</WORD> may be a verb, but its exact conjugation patterns across persons/tenses/aspects are unclear from this limited context. More data would be needed to determine the full range of inflections.</USAGE>
How is the verb <WORD>kõõpë</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?
<WORD>kõõpë</WORD> <POS>adverb</POS> <DEFINITION>again</DEFINITION>. <GRAMMATICAL>Adverbs are not conjugated in Yanomami</GRAMMATICAL>.

How is the verb <WORD>ëyëha</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>ëyëha</WORD>

1. <POS>Adverb</POS>
<DEFINITION>here, in this place</DEFINITION>
<USAGE>This usage does not seem to be conjugated as it is an adverb modifying verbs or clauses.</USAGE>
<EXAMPLES>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>Ëyëha pë kë huu.</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>He is sitting here.</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>Ëyëha pë kë huu.</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>She is sitting here.</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
</EXAMPLES>

2. <POS>Transitive Verb</POS>
<DEFINITION>to kill it</DEFINITION>
<EXAMPLES>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>en ëyëha thë ta wëtiki</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<LITERAL>you kill it ? in forest</LITERAL>
</EXAMPLES>
<GRAMMATICAL>The form 'ëyëha' may be the third person singular imperative, meaning 'kill it' when used with a subject. 'thë' could potentially mark a different tense/aspect like future or subjunctive. 'ta wëtiki' may be a locative phrase modifying where the action takes place.</GRAMMATICAL>
<RELATED_FORMS>Without more data on subject/tense marking, it is difficult to determine the full conjugation patterns for the verbal sense of 'ëyëha'.</RELATED_FORMS>

<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>He said it like this</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
</EXAMPLES>

How is the verb <WORD>tharei</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>tharei</WORD> <POS>Adverb</POS>

<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>I carry the whole tapir</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
</EXAMPLES>

<WORD>tharei</WORD> <POS>Verb</POS>
<DEFINITION>something old/habitual, always reproduced</DEFINITION>
<EXAMPLES>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>ei matiriawë pë pë pata shikõ tharei</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>this fishing line roll is well filled</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pë thë pë no wãri rë preaai tharei</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>they always remain at a disadvantage</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pë thë mãyõ tapraimi kë a tharei</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>they are not seen</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
</EXAMPLES>
<USAGE>No clear conjugation patterns are provided for <WORD>tharei</WORD> when used as a verb. The examples only show the same invariant form.</USAGE>

How is the verb <WORD>hëyëmi</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>hëyëmi</WORD> <POS>adverb</POS> <DEFINITION>this way, towards the speaker</DEFINITION>. <USAGE>As an adverb, it does not undergo conjugation like verbs do. It modifies verbs, indicating the direction or orientation of the action towards the speaker.</USAGE>

<EXAMPLES>Some examples of how <WORD>hëyëmi</WORD> is used with verbs:

- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hëyëmi heãrõhë</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> - <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>(he/she) passed by this way</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hëyëmi wa mi yapaai</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> - <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>do not return this way</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION> 
- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hëyëmi motu kë u ora</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> - <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>the flood waters are coming this way</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION></EXAMPLES>

<USAGE>Since it is an adverb and not a verb, there are no conjugations to provide for <WORD>hëyëmi</WORD> itself. It remains the same form when used with different subjects and tenses.</USAGE>
How is the verb <WORD>hei tëhë</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>hei tëhë</WORD> <POS>adverb</POS> <DEFINITION>now, immediately; from now on, henceforth; just now</DEFINITION>. <USAGE>As an adverb, it does not undergo conjugation. It modifies verbs to indicate the temporal aspect of 'now' or 'immediately'</USAGE>, <EXAMPLES>as shown in the examples provided</EXAMPLES>:

- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hei tëhë pëmaki ta iya</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>let's eat now</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hei tëhë ya huu</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>I'm leaving now</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>
- <EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>hei tëhë a hurayoma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI> <EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>he just left</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

</EXAMPLES>

How is the verb <WORD>matohi</WORD> conjugated in Yanomami?

<WORD>matohi</WORD> não é realmente um <POS>verbo</POS> em Yanomami. É descrito como:

1) Um <POS>advérbio</POS> que significa "<DEFINITION>quando eu era jovem</DEFINITION>", como no exemplo:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>matohi ya ki wãri hipëi totihioma</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>(Tradução: quando eu era jovem eu costumava oferecer muitos objetos)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

2) Um <POS>substantivo</POS> que significa "<DEFINITION>pertences de uma pessoa falecida</DEFINITION>", como nos exemplos:
<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pë toa ha pariparini, thë pë kuu mai (mit.): ni siquiera dijeron: "vamos primero a recoger los huesos quemados del muerto"</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>(Tradução: eles nem sequer disseram: "vamos primeiro recolher os ossos queimados do morto")</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

<EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>pei pusi hami matohi thë pë huruu totih i w ë: en el estómago las cenizas de los muertos se hinchan</EXAMPLE_YANOMAMI>
<EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>(Tradução: no estômago as cinzas dos mortos incham)</EXAMPLE_TRANSLATION>

Como nenhum padrão de conjugação <POS>verbal</POS> foi fornecido para '<WORD>matohi</WORD>', não posso descrever com confiança como seria conjugado como <POS>verbo</POS> em Yanomami. Os exemplos indicam que funciona como <POS>advérbio</POS> ou <POS>substantivo</POS> nesta língua, não como uma forma <POS>verbal</POS>.
